children.text: Charles Koch has been investing in residential real estate, so it’s not surprising that Koch-backed organizations have been fighting to end the federal COVID-19 eviction moratorium. The conservative billionaire appeared to get his wish this weekend, after Democrats allowed the eviction ban to expire.
On Tuesday, however, the Biden administration reversed course and announced a new eviction moratorium — so now conservative groups backed by Koch are hard at work attempting to stop the development.
Find out about these efforts and much, much more in today’s Midday Poster below, exclusively for subscribers.
“This is the delta variant of Jim Crow laws. And the only vaccination is federal voting laws.” — Sen. Raphael Warnock (D-Ga.),
Arizona Border Patrol Agents Linked To Far-Right Militias

The Number Of Tax-Free Roth IRAs has tripled
States That Cut Unemployment Early Aren’t Seeing A Hiring Boom
Polluters Don’t Pay in New ‘Polluter Pay’ Tax

on Tuesday to protect renters in areas of the U.S. that are seeing a surge in COVID-19 infections.
Two conservative groups backed by Koch that fought the original CDC policy are speaking out about the new moratorium now.
“Reissuing the CDC eviction moratorium is unlawful, irrational, & will devastate mom-and-pop housing providers everywhere,” the New Civil Liberties Alliance (NCLA)
. “NCLA will not stand for this. CDC never had legal authority to issue a nationwide eviction moratorium. Nothing has changed."

children.text: Two years into the American Revolutionary War, the Continental Army was on the verge of defeat — thanks to smallpox.

were due to the disease and other ailments. The surging virus was ravaging encampments, hindering troop movements, and hurting recruitment efforts. As General George Washington noted about smallpox in a letter, “we should have more to dread from [smallpox] than from the Sword of the Enemy.”

At the time, inoculating people with a less powerful form of smallpox was common in Europe and the British Army. But the Continental Congress, fearing the practice, banned the procedure among its troops. In February 1777, Washington decided to ignore the prohibition, writing to the governor of Virginia that the ban was “reprobated at this time, not only by the Consent and usage of [inoculations by] the greater part of the civilized World, but by our Interest and own experience of its utility.”

Washington then began history’s first mass inoculation campaign of an army in the middle of a war. The effort revitalized the Continental Army, spurred new recruitments, and is considered by some experts to be
the fledgling nation ended up winning its war for independence.

children.text: LABOR OFFICIAL CALLS FOR NEW AMAZON UNION VOTE:
On Monday, a federal labor official found that
Amazon tampered with a failed union vote

this past spring at its Bessemer, Ala., warehouse, meaning workers there could get another chance to vote to form the company’s first unionized U.S. facility. Experts say the National Labor Relations Board is likely to approve the new vote, and while such union election do-overs often fail and labor organizers’ efforts could be hampered by high turnover at the Bessemer plant, activists say the decision would be a step in the right direction. As labor lawyer Brandon Magner noted in

of the development, “The agency desperately needs the monetary fines provision of the PRO Act currently included in the reconciliation bill being considered in Congress, but at least the Labor Board still seems able to tell a strike from a ball when calling a big game.”
PRIVATE EQUITY FIRM BUYS NONPROFITS’ SOFTWARE PLATFORMS:

Apax Partners, a private equity firm, is purchasing and consolidating a trio of software companies serving nonprofits. The $2 billion deal will give Apax “a network of 650,000 non-profits, half the Fortune 500, and over 38 million donors and volunteers,”
, “Groups like Move On, Color of Change and NGP now have a PE firm with access to its data.”
